summary: This is an FBI 302 interview report of a Senior Officer Specialist at the Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC) regarding the events surrounding the death of inmate Jeffrey Epstein on August 10, 2019. The officer describes his duties, the body alarm response, and assisting in transporting Epstein to the hospital.

persons.name: Jeffrey Epstein
persons.context: The inmate who died at the Metropolitan Correctional Center on August 10, 2019. The officer responded to the body alarm, assisted in transporting him to the medical unit, and noted he was 'loose' and had to be restrained for transport.

persons.name: Lieutenant Jean
persons.context: Already present at the scene in the Special Housing Unit when the officer responded to the body alarm for Jeffrey Epstein.

events.title: Death of Jeffrey Epstein at MCC
events.description: A body alarm sounded at approximately 6:33am in the Special Housing Unit (SHU). Officers, medical staff, and Lieutenant Jean responded. Medical performed CPR on Jeffrey Epstein. He was transported via stretcher to the medical unit, then by ambulance to a hospital. The officer followed the ambulance and stayed at the hospital until relieved.

events.title: FBI Interview of MCC Officer
events.description: A Senior Officer Specialist from the Metropolitan Correctional Center was interviewed at the U.S. Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York regarding the events of August 10, 2019. The interview was conducted by FBI and OIG agents and an AUSA, in lieu of a grand jury appearance.

locations: Metropolitan Correctional Center (MCC), 150 Park Row, New York, New York
United States Attorneys Office (USAO), Southern District of New York (SDNY), 1 St. Andrews Plaza, New York, New York
keyFacts: The interview subject was a Senior Officer Specialist at the MCC who worked the morning watch (12am-8am) on August 10, 2019, the day Jeffrey Epstein died.
A body alarm went off in the Special Housing Unit (SHU) at approximately 6:33am on August 10, 2019. The officer responded and found medical staff performing CPR on Epstein.
The officer stated Epstein was 'loose' and had to be put in restraints before transport to the medical unit, but noted there was no movement by Epstein on his own.
The officer followed the ambulance to the hospital and stayed there until relieved from duty.
The officer wrote a memo about the incident, as required when responding to a body alarm.
